Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Interplay between epigenetic methylation and oxidative damage: effects on DNA stability, structure and dynamics.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The genetic information in living organisms is stored as linear polymers of four DNA elements: guanine, cytosine, adenine, and thymine. Chemical modifications of genomic DNA have principal roles in both natural gene regulation and DNA damage. In the cell, gene activity is regulated via enzymatic modification of cytosine (methylation). Cytosine modification rates are vital as their alteration can compromise cell function and organism survival. Unlike this modification of cytosine, which serves a regulatory role, modification of guanine (oxidation) is detrimental to the integrity of the genetic information. Left unrepaired, this common type of guanine damage (lesion) can lead to genome instability and mutations. In the human genome, there are many occurrences of cytosine and guanine being adjacent (clustered). Repair of a guanine lesion neighboring a modified cytosine is known to be compromised. Likewise, normal cytosine modification rates are altered within the sites containing a modified guanine. The chemical reasons for these adverse enzymological effects have yet to be determined. One of the missing links is the characterization of DNA with modified guanine and cytosine clustered together. To close this gap, the project aims to investigate the fundamental biophysics (stability, structure and dynamics) of DNA with a guanine lesion adjacent to a modified cytosine, using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) techniques along with molecular dynamics simulations. Such a comprehensive study of linked damage and regulatory modifications in DNA will be performed for the first time, pioneering new research in genome stability and regulation.

Broader Impacts: The project engages students at Western Washington University, a primarily undergraduate institution. Every effort is made to include students from minority and underprivileged populations. The participating students are involved in modern, inter-disciplinary academic research spanning areas of chemistry, biology, physics and computer science, a combination of principal scientific and instructional value. The project gives the students an early opportunity to experience the full scope of academic research in the lab. The students also communicate the results as co-authors, which further advances their professional development. As a benefit to a wider student body, some of the DNA samples developed during this investigation will be used for classes taught at Western Washington University. Overall, the project helps to integrate research with education and prepare undergraduate students for industry careers and Ph.D. studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical modifications of DNA lead to creation of non-canonical nucleotides that play principal roles both in natural gene regulation and in DNA damage. The non-canonical nucleotides 5me-C (regulatory cytosine methylation) and 8oxo-G (guanine oxidation, DNA damage) are frequently clustered within genomic CpG sites crucial for the function of the cell. Such clustering results in alteration of the cytosine methylation rates due to the adjacent 8oxo-G lesion and disruptions of the enzymatic repair of 8oxo-G caused by the adjoining 5me-C base. The molecular mechanisms of these enzymatic and cellular phenomena are not understood. With this project, we investigated for the first time the thermodyanmic (thermal) stability, solution structure and conformational dynamics of a duplex CpG site with clustered 5me-C and 8oxo-G non-canonical nucleotides.

Intellectual merits outcomes: 

1) Doubly methylated and oxidized CpG duplex samples were more stable than their unmethylated or singly methylated counterparts were, whereas single and double methylation in the non-oxidized context were not significantly different. Therefore, methylation can partially offset the destabilizing effect of oxoG in the CpG context, which may be relevant for recognition of these motifs by epigenetic factors and DNA repair enzymes.

2) The solution structures of all the double-stranded DNA samples studied showed a right-handed helical structure, typical for the canonical duplex DNA. However, 8oxo-Guanine clustered with 5me-C in certain sequence contexts were determined to alter the local conformation of the DNA backbone (BI to BII shift). This 8oxo-G-induced structural alteration can potentially lead to the changes in epigenetic enzymatic methylation rates. 

3) Solution NMR proton line-width analysis and computational molecular dynamics indicate that guanine oxidation decreases local conformational mobility of methylated CpG sites over a broad range of time scales. Moreover, the types of the dominant local motion (dynamics) of oxidized and methylated CpG samples differ from those of only oxidized and only methylated analogs as the analysis of molecular dynamics show.

In summary, clustering of 8ofo-G (guanine oxidation) and 5me-C (cytosine methylation) leads to significant alterations of stability, structure and dynamics in comparison with only-methylated and only-oxidized double stranded DNA. This information on DNA substrates is informing the future studies of oxidized/methylated DNA complexed with the relevant enzymes. 

The initial findings of the work were published in a peer-reviewed article (PMID: 27749894) and the final comprehensive data is planned for submission for peer review during the first half of 2017 (manuscript in preparation). In addition, the solution NMR structures and related NMR data for the test DNA samples were posted to the on-line public repositories (RCSB/PDB and BMRB).

 

Broader impact outcomes: 

1) During the course of the project 5 students were involved in the PI lab (2 of them are women). The students were trained in methods of modern solution NMR spectroscopy of biomolecules, computational molecular dynamics and general biochemical and biophysical methods (chromatographic purification, UV spectrophotometry etc). In addition, the participating students were exposed to the international scientific collaboration as an integral part of their work.

2) These research activities resulted in defense of one graduate (M.S.) thesis and one more scheduled for defense later in 2017. During the work, the graduate students received advanced training and had ample opportunities to lead their part of the experimental and computational work as well as to supervise undergraduate colleagues.

3) The students presented preliminary results of the project at two national conferences (Conversation on Biomolecular Structure and Dynamics and Experimental NMR Conference) with posters. Five students were co-authors of the publication reporting the initial findings. Three of the students will be co-authors of the final publication as well. 

4) A number of NMR spectra collected during the course of the work was used in the undergraduate Biophysical Chemistry class of the PI.

5) The research infrastructure in the PI lab and his Department was enhanced with equipment obtained with the NSF funding supporting the project (a high-end Linux workstation and chromatography system).
